record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Exacerbation of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 63-year-old male retired school teacher who presented to the emergency department with increasing shortness of breath, productive cough with yellow sputum, and wheezing over the past three days. The patient reports a history of COPD diagnosed five years ago, with multiple exacerbations previously managed at home with bronchodilators and steroids. The onset of symptoms was gradual, and he noticed worsening dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea earlier in the week. He denies any chest pain or hemoptysis. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. He is compliant with his medications, which include lisinopril 20 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg at bedtime, and ibuprofen as needed for joint pain. He denies any history of myocardial infarction or diabetes. He had an appendectomy at age 22, with no other surgeries reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years but quit five years ago upon his COPD diagnosis. He consumes alcohol occasionally, about 1-2 drinks per week, and denies illicit drug use. He lives alone in a one-story home and remains active by taking daily walks in the nearby park, although those have been limited due to his recent symptoms. His family consists of a supportive network of two children who live in the same city.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient is in mild respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, improving to 94% on 2 liters of nasal oxygen. Auscultation of the chest reveals diffuse wheezes and decreased breath sounds in both lung fields. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal S1 and S2 heart sounds without murmurs. There is no peripheral edema noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia with a pH of 7.37, pCO2 of 52 mmHg, and pO2 of 58 mmHg. A complete blood count reveals leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm3, likely indicating an infectious component. Interestingly, the patient’s cardiac enzymes are within normal limits, effectively ruling out myocardial infarction. Chest X-ray displays hyperinflation characteristic of COPD and a potential infiltrate in the right lower lung zone, suggestive of pneumonia.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted for further management of his COPD exacerbation. He was started on nebulized bronchodilators, systemic corticosteroids, and a course of antibiotics to cover possible bacterial infection. Additionally, supplemental oxygen was provided to maintain adequate oxygenation. Over the course of four days, the patient showed significant clinical improvement; his dyspnea reduced and his oxygen requirement decreased. A follow-up chest X-ray showed resolution of the infiltrate, supporting the diagnosis of pneumonia contributing to exacerbation. The patient was advised on smoking cessation during a thorough discharge education session, emphasizing the importance of vaccination against influenza and pneumococcus to prevent future exacerbations. He was stable at discharge with a scheduled follow-up visit in the pulmonary clinic to reassess his COPD management plan.
nl_query: Was the patient who experienced chest pain and visited the emergency room diagnosed with a myocardial infarction, treated with antiplatelet medication, and had a follow-up visit scheduled?

record:
Patient Name: John Thompson  
Age: 47  
Occupation: Construction Worker  

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Migraine headache

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 47-year-old male who presented to the emergency room with a chief complaint of severe headache over the past 24 hours. He reported that the headache began suddenly while at work, described as a pulsating sensation predominantly on the right side of his head, accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light. He described the pain as an 8/10 in intensity and noted similar episodes in the past, although none had been as debilitating. Prior self-administered treatments with over-the-counter ibuprofen provided no relief, prompting his visit to the ER.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Thompson has a history of episodic migraines diagnosed two years ago. He manages these primarily with ibuprofen, but has not been consistent with preventive treatments due to fear of medication side effects. He also has a history of hypertension, well-controlled with lisinopril, and was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), for which he takes omeprazole as needed.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John lives with his wife and two children. He has been working full-time in construction for the past 25 years, often exposed to loud noises and bright sunlight at the sites. He reports smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years and occasionally drinks beer on weekends. He denies any illicit drug use. His family history includes his mother having suffered from migraines and his father from hypertension.

record:
Patient Record

Occupation: Graphic Designer

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of asthma.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Emily Rodriguez is a 26-year-old graphic designer who presented to the emergency room with shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness that began suddenly while she was at work. She reported forgetting to carry her inhaler that day. The symptoms started with mild shortness of breath but rapidly progressed over the span of an hour, despite trying to calm herself with breathing exercises, prompting her to come in for an evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Emily was diagnosed with asthma at age 12. Her asthma is generally well-controlled with the use of a daily inhaled corticosteroid (budesonide) and as-needed use of albuterol. Besides asthma, she has a history of seasonal allergies, which have been manageable without prescription medication.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Emily lives in an apartment with her roommate in an urban area. She does not smoke and occasionally drinks alcohol socially. She is physically active and enjoys cycling. There is no significant family history of respiratory illnesses, except for her father, who has hay fever.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the ER, Emily appeared in moderate respiratory distress. Her respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute with accessory muscle use. Auscultation of her lungs revealed bilateral wheezing, more pronounced on expiration. Heart rate was 100 beats per minute, and blood pressure was 122/78 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation on room air was 92%.

LABORATORY DATA: A chest X-ray was performed, which did not show any focal lung consolidation. Arterial blood gas on room air revealed mild respiratory alkalosis (pH 7.46, PaCO2 33 mmHg, PaO2 69 mmHg). Her complete blood count was normal, with no signs of infection.

HOSPITAL COURSE: In the emergency department, Emily received immediate treatment with a nebulized bronchodilator, specifically albuterol, which led to marked improvement in her symptoms. After about an hour, her wheezing had diminished significantly, and her oxygen saturation increased to 97% on room air. She was observed for an additional two hours without recurrence of symptoms and was then discharged home with instructions to start a course of oral prednisone for the next five days to decrease airway inflammation. She was advised to follow up with her primary care physician within the week to review her asthma management plan and ensure proper technique with her inhalers. It was also recommended that she enroll in an asthma education program to reinforce management strategies.

Emily had a follow-up visit six days post-discharge with her primary care physician. During this visit, she showed good compliance with her medication regimen, reported no further episodes, and was educated on identifying triggers and the importance of never leaving home without her inhaler. Adjustments were made to her action plan to prevent future exacerbations.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 52-year-old female commercial airline pilot who presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe lower back pain that began three days ago after lifting a heavy suitcase. The pain radiated down her right leg to her foot, accompanied by numbness and tingling. She experienced difficulty standing and walking, leading to her seeking urgent medical care. She reported an inability to carry out her professional duties due to worsening symptoms.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of controlled hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril. She previously underwent arthroscopic knee surgery ten years ago following a skiing accident. No history of diabetes or cardiovascular disease is noted.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. She is married, with two adult children, and exercises regularly, participating in yoga and jogging. No illicit drug use is reported. She travels frequently for work, often across time zones, and maintains a healthy diet.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vital signs were stable upon examination. The patient had a restricted range of motion in the lumbar spine with positive straight leg raise test on the right side. Reflexes were reduced in the right ankle, and there was diminished strength of the right extensor hallucis longus muscle. Otherwise, the neurological examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Routine blood tests, including a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, were within normal limits. An MRI of the lumbar spine revealed a herniated disc at the L4-L5 level compressing the right L5 nerve root.

HOSPITAL COURSE: After initial presentation at the emergency room, the patient was admitted for further evaluation by the orthopedic and neurosurgical teams. Following discussion and evaluation, she consented to spine surgery due to the severity of her symptoms and the failure of conservative measures. She underwent a successful microdiscectomy two days after admission. Postoperatively, her radicular symptoms improved significantly, though some mild back discomfort persisted.

Her postoperative course was uncomplicated. The rehabilitation team initiated a tailored physical therapy program focusing on strengthening and flexibility, which she attended twice a day. She was discharged home on the fourth postoperative day with instructions for outpatient physical therapy and pain management using acetaminophen and gradual weaning from a short course of tramadol.

A follow-up visit was scheduled for four weeks post-surgery, during which she reported continued improvement. She was eager to resume her pilot duties with the airline company and had been compliant with her rehabilitation exercises at home. Neurological assessment at follow-up showed no residual deficits, and she was advised on strategies to prevent future back injuries, including ergonomic adjustments at work and ongoing core strengthening exercises.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John D., a 52-year-old construction worker, presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe chest pain, beginning while he was supervising a site in the afternoon. The pain was central, described as a heavy pressure, radiating to his left shoulder and accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. Despite resting in his truck for approximately 20 minutes, the pain persisted, prompting him to seek immediate medical attention. On arrival at the ER, the patient rated the pain as 8/10 in intensity.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: John has a past medical history of hypertension, diagnosed five years ago, for which he is prescribed lisinopril. He also has a significant history of hyperlipidemia, treated with atorvastatin. No previous surgeries have been reported. He has a family history of heart disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 57.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John is married with two adult children. He reports smoking one pack of cigarettes a day for the past 30 years but denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He leads a moderately active lifestyle due to his work, although he notes little formal exercise outside his job. His diet is described as high in processed foods and sodium, which contributes to his existing conditions.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, John appeared diaphoretic and anxious. His vital signs showed a blood pressure of 160/94 mmHg, heart rate of 105 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed normal S1 and S2 heart sounds with no murmurs. Lung fields were clear bilaterally. Extremities showed no edema.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads, prompting further investigation. Serial troponin levels were elevated, confirming myocardial injury. Complete blood count and electrolytes were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: John was quickly diagnosed with an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. Given the time-sensitive nature of his condition, he was immediately initiated on thrombolytic therapy with tenecteplase. Following treatment, he experienced significant pain relief and resolution of ST-segment elevation on subsequent ECGs. He was monitored in the coronary care unit for 48 hours, during which time he was initiated on dual antiplatelet therapy, beta-blockers, and a high-intensity statin regimen. He received education on lifestyle modifications, emphasizing smoking cessation and dietary changes. Cardiac rehabilitation was strongly recommended. After five days of hospitalization, John was discharged with a follow-up appointment with cardiology.

record:

He also reported shortness of breath, especially upon exertion, and a general feeling of fatigue. Mr. Sanders noted that his symptoms started after returning from a business trip to Chicago. He initially tried over-the-counter medications, which provided no relief, prompting him to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Sanders has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both managed with lifestyle modifications and medication. There is no history of diabetes, asthma, or COPD. He is compliant with his medications, which include lisinopril and atorvastatin. There is no significant surgical history, and Mr. Sanders has no known allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Sanders is a software engineer who lives in a suburban area with his wife and two teenage children. He is a former smoker, having quit ten years ago after a five-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially, averaging 3-4 drinks per week. He exercises regularly, enjoys hiking, and has no history of illicit drug use. There is no significant family history of chronic respiratory illnesses.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: During the initial exam, Mr. Sanders appeared moderately ill, with an elevated temperature of 101.8°F. Respiratory examination revealed decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lower lung field. His heart rate was elevated at 98 beats per minute, and his blood pressure was stable at 130/78 mmHg. HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Sanders was admitted to the general medical floor for further management of community-acquired pneumonia. He was started on intravenous antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and azithromycin. He received supplemental oxygen through a nasal cannula to maintain an oxygen saturation above 92%. Over the first 48 hours, his fever subsided, and his sputum production decreased. Serial blood cultures remained negative, and his white cell count normalized. The infectious disease team recommended continuing oral antibiotics upon discharge.

By the fifth day of hospitalization, Mr. Sanders demonstrated significant clinical improvement. He was transitioned to oral medications, instructed on the importance of complete antibiotic course adherence, and educated about pneumonia prevention strategies, including vaccination. record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS  
Unstable angina with suspected coronary artery disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  
John Smith, a 52-year-old male accountant, was admitted to the hospital following an emergency room visit. He experienced sudden onset chest pain while at work two days ago, described as a tight, squeezing sensation in the center of his chest, radiating to his left arm. The pain drove him to visit the emergency department, where initial workup suggested angina. He received nitroglycerin, which alleviated his symptoms, prompting further evaluation for coronary artery disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  
John has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which have been managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. He also has a past history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He denies any history of diabetes, specific cardiac conditions, or previous surgeries.

John lives with his spouse in a suburban area and works full-time in a sedentary job as an accountant. He is physically inactive, mentioning occasional light walks over the weekends. The cardiothoracic team discussed the possibility of elective percutaneous coronary intervention, which is being considered. Upon discharge, John was stable, pain-free on a regimen of nitroglycerin as needed, with plans for a follow-up visit with his cardiologist in one week to reassess his symptoms and discuss intervention options further. Peripheral pulses were palpable and equal.

He was promptly moved to the coronary care unit where a thrombolytic therapy was administered with alteplase, leading to marked symptom relief within the first hour. record:

Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with respiratory failure.

John D., a 72-year-old retired shipyard worker, presented to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath, wheezing, and productive cough over the past five days. He also noted increased sputum production, which has changed to a greenish color, accompanied by intermittent low-grade fevers. He denies any recent chest pain or palpitations. His daughter noticed he had been particularly drowsy and disoriented in the 24 hours prior to arrival.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  
The patient has a known history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease diagnosed ten years ago and is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history, having quit 5 years ago. He also has hypertension, managed with lisinopril, and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes atorvastatin. He has a history of a myocardial infarction 3 years prior and is maintained on low-dose aspirin and a beta-blocker.

SOCIAL HISTORY  
John lives in an assisted living community and receives regular visits from family. He is divorced and has one adult daughter. Aside from smoking, he has no history of alcohol or illicit drug use. Previously employed in a shipyard, he was constantly exposed to environmental pollutants and heavy dust, contributing to his respiratory ailments.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  
On examination, the patient appeared in moderate respiratory distress, using accessory muscles to breathe. Oxygen saturation was 87% on room air, which improved to 95% on 3L/min via nasal cannula. His temperature was 100.2°F, heart rate 105bpm, and blood pressure 140/85 mmHg. Pulmonary examination revealed decreased breath sounds bilaterally with end-expiratory wheezes. The cardiovascular exam was unremarkable, except for a regular tachycardia. Extremities were without edema.

LABORATORY DATA  
Initial lab workup showed an elevated white blood cell count of 15,000/mm³ suggestive of infection and arterial blood gases indicated respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.29, pCO2 of 55 mm Hg, and pO2 of 58 mmHg. A chest X-ray revealed hyperinflated lungs and a right lower lobe infiltrate suggestive of pneumonia. Inflammatory markers such as CRP were elevated.

HOSPITAL COURSE  
The patient was admitted to the medical floor for management of acute COPD exacerbation with suspected superimposed bacterial pneumonia. He was started on a course of intravenous antibiotics consisting of azithromycin and ceftriaxone, along with corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation. Bronchodilators were administered via a nebulizer, and oxygen therapy was maintained. Over several days, his respiratory symptoms gradually improved, his sputum production decreased, and his oxygen requirements lessened. By the end of the hospital stay, he was ambulating without significant distress, and his oxygen levels remained stable on room air. His cognitive status returned to baseline following correction of hypoxia. record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 67-year-old male, Mr. Robert Martin, who presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of chest pain while gardening at home. The chest pain began two hours before his arrival at the hospital and was described as a severe, crushing pain radiating to his left shoulder and jaw. He had associated symptoms of shortness of breath and diaphoresis. In the ER, his initial ECG showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads, suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction, prompting immediate cardiology consultation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Martin has a significant medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. He underwent a right total knee arthroplasty five years ago and has no known drug allergies. He has been on antihypertensives and metformin for diabetes control, along with atorvastatin for cholesterol management.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Martin is a retired high school math teacher who lives with his wife. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally, about one glass of wine per week. He remains physically active, enjoying gardening and walking. He has two adult children who live out of state.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the emergency room, Mr. Martin appeared in moderate distress. His vital signs included a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg, heart rate of 98 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds with no murmurs, but jugular venous distension was observed. Respiratory examination showed mild basal crackles bilaterally. Abdominal examination was unremarkable, and there was no peripheral edema.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests revealed an elevated troponin level of 1.8 ng/mL. Complete blood count and basic metabolic profile were within normal limits. Fasting lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Martin was quickly triaged to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for emergency percutaneous coronary intervention. He was found to have a 95% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery, which was successfully treated with a drug-eluting stent. Post-procedural recovery was uneventful. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, along with adjustments to his antihypertensive and diabetic regimens. During his hospitalization, Mr. Martin participated in cardiac rehabilitation counseling and was educated on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and increased physical activity tailored to his condition. He was discharged on the third hospital day with plans for close outpatient follow-up with cardiology and primary care to monitor his recovery and manage his chronic conditions.

He tried resting and taking his prescribed nitroglycerin with no relief, prompting the ER visit. 

Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past seven years. He is a non-smoker but has a family history of coronary artery disease, with both his father and older brother having passed away from heart attacks in their fifties. Blood pressure was elevated at 160/95 mmHg, heart rate was 110 beats per minute, and he was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24. Laboratory Data: Initial lab work showed elevated cardiac troponins, confirming myocardial injury. The chest X-ray was unremarkable, while the EKG revealed significant ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads, consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

During his stay, diabetes management was optimized with revisions in his metformin dosing, and lifestyle modifications were discussed in detail. He was educated about the importance of adhering to his medication regimen, including statins, to prevent further cardiovascular events.

record:
Admission Diagnosis: Acute Cholecystitis

History of Present Illness: The patient is a 34-year-old female accountant who presented to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began abruptly two days prior to admission. The pain was constant, sharp, and radiated to the right shoulder. She rated it as 8/10 in intensity and reported associated nausea and vomiting, though without fever. The patient had initially tried managing the pain with over-the-counter ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. Due to the increasing severity of symptoms, she sought medical attention. There was no recent history of illness, travel, or similar episodes in the past.

Past Medical History: The patient reported a history of irritable bowel syndrome, managed primarily through dietary modifications. She has no history of operations or known allergies. The patient is currently not on any regular medications besides an occasional multivitamin supplement.

Social History: She is married with two young children and works full time as an accountant. She does not smoke cigarettes, consumes alcohol socially, and is a non-drug user. Her diet consists of regular meals, often high in fried and fatty foods due to her busy work schedule, although she has been attempting to incorporate more vegetables and fruits lately. 

Physical Examination: On physical examination, the patient appeared in mild distress due to pain. Her vital signs were notable for mild tachycardia with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute and blood pressure of 126/78 mmHg. Temperature was normal. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right upper quadrant with positive Murphy's sign. There was no rebound tenderness or guarding, and bowel sounds were present. Other systemic examinations revealed no abnormalities.

Laboratory Data: Initial lab work demonstrated mild leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 12,500/mm³, indicating possible inflammation or infection. Liver function tests and amylase levels were within normal limits, although there was a mild elevation in alkaline phosphatase. An abdominal ultrasound was performed, revealing gallstones and thickening of the gallbladder wall, consistent with cholecystitis.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital for further management of acute cholecystitis. She was started on intravenous fluids and received analgesics for pain control. Broad-spectrum antibiotics were initiated to address possible bacterial infection. A surgical consultation was obtained, and the patient was scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The surgery was performed without complications, and the patient recovered well postoperatively. She was mobilized on the second postoperative day and dietary intake was gradually resumed, starting with clear fluids and advancing as tolerated. The patient's pain was markedly reduced, and she was discharged on the fourth hospital day with a prescription for oral analgesics as needed and instructions to follow a low-fat diet. She was advised to follow up with her primary care physician in one week and with her surgeon in two weeks for postoperative assessment.

record:

Occupation: Construction Worker

Discharge Date: March 14, 2023

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Community-acquired pneumonia

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Lucas Thompson, a 55-year-old male, presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of worsening cough, fever, and shortness of breath. The symptoms began with mild fatigue and a non-productive cough but progressed to dyspnea and chest pain, particularly on inspiration. He denied any recent travels or sick contacts but mentioned continuing to work outdoors despite inclement weather conditions, which could have contributed to his current state.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Thompson's medical history is significant for hypertension, for which he is on lisinopril 10 mg daily. He also has a history of seasonal allergic rhinitis, managed with over-the-counter antihistamines. There is no history of previous respiratory conditions such as asthma, and he has never required hospitalization for pulmonary issues before.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Lucas is a lifelong resident of the area, living with his spouse and two adult children. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history, having quit approximately five years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally but does not use illicit drugs. His work as a construction worker involves physical labor outdoors, even in adverse weather conditions, which may have exposed him to respiratory irritants.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On admission, Lucas appeared acutely ill and was in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs were as follows: temperature 101.5°F, heart rate 105 beats per minute, respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute, blood pressure 136/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation was 89% on room air. Lung auscultation revealed crackles in the right lower lobe. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory investigations showed a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³ indicating leukocytosis. Chest X-ray demonstrated a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. Influenza and COVID-19 tests were negative, and blood cultures were pending at the time of admission. 

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Thompson was admitted to the medical ward for intravenous antibiotics and supportive care. He was started on ceftriaxone 1g IV daily and azithromycin 500 mg IV on the first day, followed by 250 mg IV daily. Supplemental oxygen was provided via nasal cannula to maintain adequate oxygenation, and he was assessed by the respiratory therapy team for chest physiotherapy to aid in secretion clearance.

Over the next few days, Lucas showed significant clinical improvement. His fever resolved, and he was able to breathe comfortably on room air. Blood cultures remained negative throughout his hospital stay. By day four, he was transitioned to oral antibiotics and discharged home with a prescription for azithromycin 250 mg daily to complete a total of ten days of antibiotic therapy.

At discharge, Lucas was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with his primary care physician in one week and was counseled regarding smoking cessation and vaccinations for pneumococcus and influenza to prevent future occurrences. He was in agreement with the plan and expressed determination to adhere to lifestyle modifications and follow-up care.

Occupation: Retired Engineer

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mr. Thompson presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain that began approximately three hours prior to admission. The pain radiated to his left arm and was accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. He reported feeling increasingly fatigued and unwell over the last few days but attributed it to recent travel stress. He denied any recent fever or upper respiratory symptoms.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Thompson has a history of hypertension, diagnosed 10 years ago, and hyperlipidemia. He has been on lisinopril and atorvastatin, both of which he takes consistently. He had a cholecystectomy seven years ago and denies any history of diabetes or prior cardiac issues. 

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Thompson is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He lives with his wife and enjoys gardening and playing golf. He retired five years ago after a 37-year career in engineering. He travels frequently to visit his adult children who live across the country.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mr. Thompson appeared diaphoretic and in mild distress. Vital signs were significant for elevated blood pressure at 148/92 mmHg and a heart rate of 96 bpm. Cardiac examination revealed an S4 gallop, with no murmurs. Lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdomen was soft and non-tender, and no peripheral edema was noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads. Troponins were elevated at 1.2 ng/mL on admission, rising to 5.6 ng/mL six hours later. Lipid panel showed LDL levels at 145 mg/dL, which was increased compared to previous results. Kidney function tests, liver enzymes, and complete blood count were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Thompson was promptly started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, as well as atorvastatin, and received thrombolytic therapy in the emergency department. He was admitted to the coronary care unit for further monitoring and management. Over the next 48 hours, Mr. Thompson's condition stabilized. He was evaluated by cardiology and underwent a cardiac catheterization, which revealed a significant stenosis in the right coronary artery. A drug-eluting stent was placed successfully. Following the procedure, he was monitored in the ICU for 24 hours and then transferred to the step-down unit. He participated in cardiac rehabilitation sessions and was counseled on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and regular physical activity. Mr. Thompson was discharged on hospital day five with a follow-up appointment scheduled with cardiology in two weeks. Upon discharge, he was advised to continue his medications, now including a beta-blocker and an ACE inhibitor. He was instructed to avoid strenuous activities until cleared by his cardiologist. Mr. Thompson expressed understanding of his condition and the importance of adherence to medication and lifestyle changes to prevent future cardiac events.

record:
Patient Record: 

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Herniated disc L4-L5 with acute exacerbation of low back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John Smith is a 34-year-old male construction worker who presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe lower back pain radiating to the left leg. The pain began two days ago when he was lifting a heavy load at work and has progressively worsened, resulting in difficulty walking and sleeping. He describes the pain as sharp and stabbing, with associated numbness and tingling in the left leg extending to the foot. Prior to this episode, he had been experiencing intermittent back discomfort over the past several months, but never severe enough to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension managed with lisinopril and episodic migraine headaches for which he occasionally takes over-the-counter ibuprofen. He denies any history of trauma or previous surgical interventions.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John lives with his wife and two young children. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially, limiting his consumption to weekends. He reports no illicit drug use. His work as a construction worker involves frequent heavy lifting and bending. He tries to maintain a healthy lifestyle but admits that his physical activity is primarily work-related rather than scheduled exercise.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient is in moderate distress due to back pain. His vital signs are stable. Neurological examination reveals decreased strength in the left lower extremity, particularly in the dorsiflexors of the foot, with positive straight leg raise test on the left. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in the left L5 dermatome. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced at the left Achilles. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar paraspinal muscles.

LABORATORY DATA: Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were within normal limits. An MRI of the lumbar spine showed a large herniated disc at the L4-L5 level, compressing the left nerve root.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was started on a regimen of oral steroids and muscle relaxants to alleviate inflammation and muscle spasms. Pain management included a combination of acetaminophen and a low-dose opioid. Despite conservative management, there was minimal improvement in symptoms, and due to the severity of nerve compression, surgical intervention was deemed necessary. He underwent a microdiscectomy to relieve the nerve root impingement. Postoperatively, he experienced immediate relief from leg pain and was mobilized the next day with the help of physical therapy focused on strengthening and flexibility exercises. He was discharged home on the third postoperative day with instructions to avoid heavy lifting and to gradually increase activity as pain allows.

FOLLOWUP VISIT: Two weeks post-surgery, the patient returned for follow-up. He reported significant improvement in back pain and resolution of leg symptoms, with only mild discomfort related to the surgical site. He was advised to continue physical therapy and was cleared to return to light duty work within four to six weeks, with another follow-up appointment scheduled in a month to reassess his progress and potential return to full duty.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute pyelonephritis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 32-year-old female graphic designer who presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressive right flank pain, fever, and dysuria. She reported chills and nausea but denied vomiting or hematuria. The pain was dull, radiating to the front of the abdomen, and rated at 7 out of 10 in intensity.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections, with three episodes in the past two years. She also has mild asthma, managed with an as-needed inhaler. There is no history of diabetes, hypertension, or previous surgeries.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives alone in an apartment and works full-time as a graphic designer. She does not smoke or use recreational drugs and consumes alcohol socially, about two to three drinks per week. She exercises irregularly, mostly walking, and follows a balanced diet. There is no significant family history of renal or urological conditions.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient appeared mildly distressed due to pain. Her temperature was 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate was 98 beats per minute, and blood pressure was 118/74 mmHg. Abdomen examination revealed right costovertebral angle tenderness. There were no abdominal masses or organomegaly. Breath sounds were normal, and there were no signs of wheezing.

LABORATORY DATA: Urinalysis showed significant pyuria and bacteriuria. Blood tests revealed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,000/µL, and a renal profile indicated normal renal function. Blood cultures were obtained and pending. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed right acute pyelonephritis without evidence of obstruction or calculi.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotic therapy. She was started on ceftriaxone, with her pain managed by acetaminophen, and hydration status maintained with IV fluids. Cultures later grew Escherichia coli, sensitive to the prescribed antibiotics. Over the course of her three-day admission, she responded well to treatment with significant improvement in symptoms. Her fever resolved within 48 hours, and flank pain diminished considerably. She was educated on preventative measures for recurrent infections, including increased water intake and frequent voiding. The patient was discharged on oral ciprofloxacin to complete a 10-day course and arranged for a follow-up appointment with outpatient urology to evaluate recurrent urinary tract infections. Patient education was provided regarding the importance of adhering to her treatment regimen and monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms.

record:

Gender: Male  
Occupation: Software Developer  

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute asthma exacerbation

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Alex Morales, a 35-year-old software developer, presented to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness that began three days ago. He reported difficulty breathing following exposure to dust while cleaning his garage. Initial relief from his rescue inhaler was temporary. Yesterday, the symptoms worsened, leading him to visit the ER. He denied fever, recent respiratory infections, or smoking but admitted to a history of seasonal allergies. In the ER visit, Alex was diagnosed with an asthma exacerbation and received a bronchodilator treatment, leading to partial relief of symptoms.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Alex has a history of asthma since childhood, requiring the use of inhalers. He has experienced similar exacerbations in the past but has not been hospitalized for his condition. Other medical conditions include mild hypertension, managed with losartan, and allergic rhinitis for which he occasionally takes loratadine.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Alex lives with his partner in a suburban home. He works full-time as a software developer, spending long hours in front of a computer. He does not smoke and reports drinking alcohol socially, about 1–2 times a week. He exercises infrequently but enjoys hiking on weekends. There is no history of illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: In the emergency department, Alex was alert and in mild respiratory distress. Vital signs included: blood pressure 128/82 mmHg, heart rate 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, temperature 36.6°C, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Lung examination revealed diffuse wheezing bilaterally with prolonged expiration but no crackles or decreased breath sounds. Heart sounds were normal, and there were no signs of cyanosis or peripheral edema.

LABORATORY DATA: Routine laboratory tests were unremarkable. CBC showed normal white cell count and differential. A chest X-ray was performed, which did not demonstrate any acute pathology such as pneumonia or pneumothorax. Pulmonary function tests showed a decrease in FEV1, consistent with a reversible airway obstruction.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Upon admission, Alex was treated with nebulized albuterol and systemic corticosteroids. Following the administration of bronchodilators, his respiratory symptoms improved significantly. He received supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate oxygen saturation above 96%. The treatment plan included continuation of inhaled corticosteroids to prevent future exacerbations. An allergist consultation was recommended to reassess his allergen triggers and refine his long-term asthma management. Alex was educated on asthma exacerbation triggers and the importance of adherence to his prescribed controller therapy. After 48 hours of monitoring and significant symptomatic improvement, Alex was discharged home with follow-up instructions to see his primary care physician and the allergist within the next two weeks. He was advised to avoid known asthma triggers and was given an updated asthma action plan.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS  
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  
James Carter, a 58-year-old male, presented to the emergency department complaining of increased shortness of breath, wheezing, and productive cough with greenish sputum for the past three days. He reported that his symptoms began worsening following an upper respiratory tract infection. Despite using his prescribed inhalers more frequently, his symptoms did not improve. James, a retired truck driver, noted that he tends to have similar episodes during the winter months but none as severe as this.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  
James has a significant history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diagnosed 10 years ago. He also has a history of hypertension, which is well managed with amlodipine. James had a myocardial infarction five years ago and subsequently underwent angioplasty. He is on daily aspirin and atorvastatin for secondary prevention.

SOCIAL HISTORY  
James is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history, having quit five years ago following his heart attack. He lives with his wife and occasionally babysits his grandchildren. James does not consume alcohol but is known to chew tobacco. He rarely exercises, citing difficulty breathing and joint pains as primary barriers.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  
Upon examination, James appeared in mild respiratory distress. His temperature was 99°F, blood pressure 148/88 mmHg, pulse rate 92 beats per minute, and respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute with oxygen saturation at 89% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs revealed diffuse wheezing bilaterally with decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes. Cardiovascular examination was unremarkable except for a slight S4 gallop.

LABORATORY DATA  
Complete blood count revealed a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm³, suggestive of an infection. The C-reactive protein level was elevated. Arterial blood gas analysis showed mild respiratory acidosis with partial pressure of carbon dioxide at 48 mmHg and partial pressure of oxygen at 60 mmHg on room air. A chest X-ray showed hyperinflated lungs and no new infiltrates, consistent with COPD.

HOSPITAL COURSE  
James was admitted to the medical ward for further management of his exacerbation. He was started on intravenous antibiotics and corticosteroids, and regular nebulization with bronchodilators was initiated. Supplemental oxygen was provided to maintain saturation above 92%. During the hospital stay, a respiratory therapist worked with James on breathing exercises. After three days of treatment, his symptoms significantly improved, and he was able to ambulate without shortness of breath. Before discharge, a pulmonologist reviewed his inhaler technique and recommended the addition of a long-acting muscarinic antagonist to his regimen. James was discharged on the fifth hospital day with instructions to follow up in the outpatient clinic in two weeks.

record:
Admission Diagnosis: Acute Ischemic Stroke

History of Present Illness: Mr. Robert Wells, a 68-year-old retired school principal, was brought to the Emergency Room by his wife after she noticed sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. These symptoms began approximately one hour before their arrival at the ER. Mr. Wells also reported a mild headache but denied any preceding trauma, nausea, or vomiting.

Past Medical History: Mr. Wells has a history of hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril daily. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia two years ago and is currently on atorvastatin. There is no previous history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks. He underwent a cholecystectomy five years ago without complications. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at age 60.

Social History: Mr. Wells is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally, limited to social gatherings. He lives at home with his wife and enjoys regular walks in the park. He does not use illicit drugs and abstains from caffeine. As a retired educator, he volunteers at the local community center tutoring children in mathematics.

Physical Examination: On examination, Mr. Wells was alert but exhibited dysarthria and right facial droop. There was 2/5 strength in his right upper and lower extremities. His left side had full strength. Reflexes were brisk on the right and normal on the left. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg, heart rate of 82 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 36.8°C. Cardiac, lung, and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.

Laboratory Data: Complete blood count and metabolic panel were within normal limits. His LDL cholesterol was slightly elevated at 130 mg/dL. Coagulation studies were normal, and a toxicology screen was negative.

Hospital Course: In the ER, a non-contrast CT scan of the head was promptly performed, showing no hemorrhage, and the clinical diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke was made. Given the timeframe of his symptom onset, Mr. Wells was deemed eligible for thrombolysis. He received intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (IV tPA) within 90 minutes of arrival with subsequent notable improvement in symptoms.

Mr. Wells was transferred to the stroke unit for post-thrombolysis observation. Over the next few days, his right-sided weakness improved, and speech clarity returned. An MRI confirmed the diagnosis of an acute ischemic event in the left MCA territory. Carotid Doppler ultrasound displayed moderate stenosis.

A multidisciplinary team, including a neurologist, physical therapist, and dietitian, outlined a comprehensive rehabilitation plan. Mr. Wells attended daily rehabilitation sessions focusing on motor strength and coordination. His antihypertensive regimen was adjusted, and a tailored diet plan was introduced to better manage his cholesterol levels.

Upon discharge, Mr. Wells was ambulatory with a cane and exhibited significant functional recovery. He was scheduled for outpatient rehab sessions and advised on risk factor modification, including continued adherence to a low-fat diet and regular physical activity, further supported by educational resources provided at discharge. Mr. Wells and his wife were educated on recognizing early stroke symptoms to ensure prompt future care if needed.

record:

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Jane Thompson, a 29-year-old school teacher, presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of worsening abdominal pain. She described a sharp, persistent pain in the right lower quadrant that began diffusely around the umbilicus. Jane also reported experiencing nausea and anorexia, as well as a low-grade fever measured at home. Her last bowel movement was two days prior to admission, and she noted a decrease in appetite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Jane has a medical history significant for mild persistent asthma, for which she uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. She has no history of surgeries and no known drug allergies. She underwent a tonsillectomy at age 12 and has been generally healthy since.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Jane lives with her partner and a 2-year-old son in a suburban neighborhood. She is a non-smoker, occasionally consumes alcohol socially, and reports no illicit drug use. She maintains an active lifestyle, regularly jogging three times a week, and is keen on healthy eating, although recently her routine was disrupted due to a school examination period.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Jane was found to be in moderate distress due to pain. Her temperature was 100°F, heart rate 98 beats per minute, blood pressure 118/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. A Comprehensive Metabolic Panel was unremarkable. Urinalysis was negative for infection. An abdominal ultrasound suggested an inflamed appendix, and a subsequent CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis of acute appendicitis, showing a dilated appendix measuring 1.2 cm with surrounding fat stranding.

Pain was managed effectively with acetaminophen and, when necessary, low-dose narcotics.

Jane recovered well, with the surgical team noting no signs of complications such as infection or bowel obstruction. She was ambulated on postoperative day one and progressed to a regular diet without difficulty. By day two, she was passing flatus, and bowel function had returned to normal. Physical therapy was not deemed necessary, and discharge planning was initiated. 

Jane was discharged home on postoperative day three with instructions to rest and limit physical activity for at least two weeks. She was educated on wound care and signs of infection, and a follow-up appointment was scheduled with the surgical team in two weeks to monitor her recovery.

record:

record:
Admission Diagnosis: Acute Gastritis

History of Present Illness: A 52-year-old male presents to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The patient describes the pain as a burning sensation located primarily in the upper abdominal region, which began approximately 12 hours prior to admission. He reports associated nausea and occasional vomiting but denies any hematemesis or melena. The pain worsened after eating and is somewhat alleviated by antacids. Additionally, the patient experienced increased stress at work over the past few weeks, which he believes might have exacerbated the condition.

Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension managed with lisinopril. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia three years ago and takes atorvastatin. The patient also has a family history of gastrointestinal issues, including his father, who had peptic ulcers.

Social History: The patient works as an accountant and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle due to his job requirements. He admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years and occasionally consumes alcohol socially, though he denies excessive use. His diet is high in spicy and fatty foods, which could be contributing to his gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient lives alone and reports moderate caffeine intake, mainly in the form of coffee.

Physical Examination: On physical examination, the patient is in mild distress due to discomfort. He is afebrile, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and his heart rate is 88 beats per minute. Abdominal examination reveals epigastric tenderness upon palpation without rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are present. No hepatomegaly or splenomegaly is noted.

Laboratory Data: Laboratory results demonstrated a normal complete blood count. Comprehensive metabolic panel results were within normal limits, except for a mild elevation in liver function tests, likely due to his history of alcohol use. Helicobacter pylori testing returned negative. An abdominal ultrasound showed no gallstones or evidence of liver disease.

Hospital Course: The patient was diagnosed with acute gastritis, likely exacerbated by his lifestyle and dietary habits. He was admitted for observation and management of his symptoms. Intravenous fluids were initiated, and he was started on a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy, specifically omeprazole, to reduce gastric acid secretion and promote healing of the gastric mucosa. Smoking cessation counseling was provided, and the patient was advised to reduce alcohol and caffeine intake, along with dietary modifications to avoid irritating foods.

Over the course of his hospitalization, the patient's abdominal pain significantly improved with PPI treatment, and his nausea resolved. He was discharged home on day two with a prescription for omeprazole to continue daily for a month, along with dietary guidelines to prevent recurrence. Follow-up with his primary care physician was arranged, emphasizing the importance of lifestyle changes to decrease the risk of future episodes.

He had rhonchi and dullness to percussion over the same area, suggestive of consolidation.

LABORATORY DATA: A complete blood count showed leukocytosis with a left shift. C-reactive protein was elevated. The chest X-ray indicated a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. Arterial blood gases showed mild respiratory alkalosis.

He was started on intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin to cover community-acquired pneumonia. Nebulized bronchodilators were administered every four hours, and a respiratory therapist was involved for chest physiotherapy. Intravenous methylprednisolone was initiated to reduce airway inflammation. Over the course of four days, the patient's symptoms significantly improved; his oxygen requirements decreased and wheezing subsided. He was transitioned to oral prednisone and discharged with instructions for a broad-spectrum inhaler and antibiotics. A pulmonologist follow-up visit was arranged for ongoing asthma management and to reassess lung function in two weeks. The patient was advised on the importance of consistent follow-up to prevent recurrent exacerbations, especially during travel.

record:

The patient mentioned the onset of respiratory symptoms following a recent upper respiratory tract infection, which he attempted to manage at home with over-the-counter medications and his usual COPD inhalers but found no relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a significant history of COPD with frequent exacerbations, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Upon auscultation, diminished breath sounds with bilateral wheezes and crackles, particularly in the right lower lobe, were evident. The cardiovascular exam was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: A complete blood count revealed leukocytosis with a left shift. C-reactive protein was elevated, indicating inflammation. The patient was counseled on pneumonia prevention, including appropriate periodical vaccinations, and educated on recognizing early symptoms of respiratory infections to seek timely medical attention. record:

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: James Anderson, a 32-year-old software engineer, presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of severe abdominal pain. The pain began as vague discomfort around his umbilical region but intensified to a sharp, persistent ache in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. He also reported experiencing nausea and a low-grade fever of 100.8°F. James noted that the pain worsened upon movement, and he was unable to find relief in any position, prompting urgent medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: James' medical history is notable for well-controlled asthma since childhood, managed with an as-needed albuterol inhaler. He denies any prior surgeries, significant illnesses, or hospitalizations. He has no history of hypertension, diabetes, or hyperlipidemia.

SOCIAL HISTORY: James lives in Seattle with his partner and works for a tech company, where he spends long hours seated at a computer. He exercises sporadically on weekends by hiking with friends in the nearby Cascade Mountains. He smokes occasionally, particularly in social settings, and consumes alcohol moderately, typically about two to three times per week. He denies any illicit drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, James was found to be in moderate distress due to pain. He was afebrile with stable vital signs except for mild tachycardia. Abdominal examination revealed significant tenderness and guarding in the right lower quadrant with a positive rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds were hypoactive, and no masses or hepatosplenomegaly were noted.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 14,000/mm³, indicating leukocytosis. C-reactive protein was elevated. Liver function tests and kidney function tests were within normal limits. A urine analysis ruled out urinary tract infection.

HOSPITAL COURSE: James was admitted to the surgical unit with a diagnosis of acute appendicitis. A preoperative abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of an inflamed appendix. He was counseled about the need for an appendectomy, to which he consented. He received intravenous antibiotics preoperatively. The surgical procedure was performed laparoscopically without complications. Postoperatively, James was monitored closely and experienced an uneventful recovery. Pain was managed adequately with acetaminophen. He was discharged on postoperative day two with instructions to avoid strenuous activity for a few weeks and to follow up with his primary care physician in one week for wound inspection. James was advised to gradually resume his daily activities and to seek medical attention should any fever, severe pain, or other concerning symptoms arise.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute ischemic stroke

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 78-year-old retired schoolteacher who was brought to the emergency room by her daughter after experiencing sudden onset of slurred speech and right-sided weakness. These symptoms began approximately two hours prior to her arrival. Her daughter reported that the patient was well and conversing normally earlier that morning when they had breakfast together. She denied any recent trauma, headaches, or seizures, and there was no history of similar episodes in the past.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, which has been poorly controlled, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. She also has a history of osteoarthritis and mild heart failure for which she has been taking prescribed medications including lisinopril, atorvastatin, and warfarin. The patient had an appendectomy in her 40s but otherwise has no significant surgical history.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a widow who lives independently in a retirement community. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She is physically active, attending a bi-weekly tai chi class at her community center. She has two children who live nearby and are her primary support system.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was found to be alert but had dysarthria. She had right-sided facial droop, and weakness was noted in her right arm and leg, with motor power graded as 2/5 on that side. Sensory examination showed decreased sensation on the right side of the body. The rest of the neurological examination was unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests revealed elevated LDL cholesterol levels and an INR of 1.8, which were subtherapeutic given her atrial fibrillation. A CT scan of the head showed early signs of an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory. An ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Following the emergency room visit, the patient was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke attributed to cardioembolism given her known atrial fibrillation. She was administered intravenous thrombolysis therapy promptly within the therapeutic window without any complications. Her INR was optimized, and she was transitioned to a direct oral anticoagulant for better stroke prevention management. The patient's blood pressure and cholesterol were managed with an adjusted medication regimen, improving both control and efficacy.

The patient was admitted to the stroke unit, where she underwent a structured rehabilitation program. This included physical, occupational, and speech therapy tailored to regain her motor skills, speech clarity, and independent functionality. The team planned a comprehensive discharge strategy, including home safety assessments and continued outpatient rehabilitation to further enhance her recovery. The patient made gradual improvements over her hospital stay, regaining some motor function on her right side. She was discharged to her daughter's care with a follow-up appointment scheduled with her primary care provider and a cardiologist to assess ongoing stroke risk management.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Suspected Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mrs. Laura Jenkins, a 62-year-old retired schoolteacher, presented to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of left-side facial droop and slurred speech lasting about 15 minutes. Her symptoms resolved en route to the hospital. She had no previous similar episodes. She did not report any headaches, loss of consciousness, or seizure activity. Her husband, who accompanied her, noted that she appeared confused and had difficulty finding words during the episode.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Her medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago, well-controlled on lisinopril 10 mg daily. She is also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and is currently on atorvastatin 20 mg nightly. She has no history of diabetes, heart disease, or previous strokes. Her surgical history includes a cholecystectomy five years ago. She is up to date on all age-appropriate cancer screenings and vaccinations.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Laura lives with her husband in a suburban area and enjoys gardening and volunteering at the local library. She has a 10-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 15 years ago. She drinks wine socially, consuming approximately one glass once or twice a week. She denies any illicit drug use and has no recent travel history. Her family history is significant for a mother who suffered from a stroke at age 70.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Laura was alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her blood pressure was 140/88 mm Hg, pulse 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations were unremarkable. Neurologic examination revealed no facial asymmetry or speech difficulty, and there was no sensory or motor deficit. Reflexes were symmetric, and her gait was steady.

LABORATORY DATA: Routine blood work, including a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and coagulation profile, was within normal limits. Lipid profile showed total cholesterol of 210 mg/dL, LDL 130 mg/dL, and HDL 50 mg/dL. A non-contrast head CT was performed, which showed no acute intracranial hemorrhage or infarction. An EKG showed normal sinus rhythm.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Laura was admitted for observation and further evaluation. A carotid Doppler ultrasound revealed mild atherosclerotic changes but no significant stenosis. A transthoracic echocardiogram did not reveal any thrombus or cardiac embolic source. Given the clinical picture, she was diagnosed with a transient ischemic attack. She was counseled on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and increased physical activity, to manage her cardiovascular risk factors. Her antihypertensive regimen was optimized, and aspirin 81 mg daily was added for stroke prevention. After 24 hours of observation without recurrence of symptoms, she was deemed stable for discharge with a referral for outpatient follow-up in the stroke prevention clinic. Laura and her husband were educated on the warning signs of stroke and the importance of immediate action should symptoms recur.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute myocardial ischemia with unstable angina.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 55-year-old male construction worker who presented to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of sudden onset of chest pain. The pain commenced while he was lifting a heavy object at work, described as a squeezing sensation radiating to the left arm and jaw, accompanied by diaphoresis and shortness of breath. He initially tried to rest, but the symptoms persisted, prompting an emergency visit. Upon arrival at the ER, he reported no relief of symptoms.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago, for which he is on amlodipine, 5 mg once daily. He has a history of hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin, 20 mg daily. Non-smoker, no prior history of heart disease, or diabetes. Surgical history is significant for an appendectomy 20 years ago.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient lives with his wife and has three children. He is employed full-time as a construction worker, a job which occasionally involves strenuous physical tasks. He drinks alcohol socially, about 3-4 beers per week, and follows a diet high in red meat and carbohydrates, acknowledging limited physical exercise outside of work-related activity.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, the patient appeared anxious but was alert and oriented. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg, a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rhythm without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Respiratory, abdominal, and neurologic examinations were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory studies showed elevated cardiac troponin levels I, suggestive of myocardial injury. Lipid profile revealed elevated LDL cholesterol at 145 mg/dL. Basic metabolic panel and complete blood count were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: In the emergency department, the patient was diagnosed with angina. He was immediately treated with nitroglycerin sublingually, leading to noticeable improvement in chest pain. An ECG showed ST-segment depressions in leads V4-V6 which reverted to baseline following treatment with nitroglycerin. The patient was admitted to the telemetry unit for further monitoring and management of potential myocardial ischemia. He was started on a low-dose aspirin and a beta-blocker, metoprolol. An echocardiogram performed showed preserved ejection fraction with no wall motion abnormalities. He was counseled on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and incorporating regular moderate exercise into his routine. A follow-up with cardiology was scheduled, and he was discharged with a prescription for clopidogrel in addition to his current medications. The patient was advised to avoid heavy lifting and strenuous activities until cleared by his cardiologist. His prognosis is considered good with adherence to medical therapy and lifestyle modifications.

record:
Admission Diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of COPD

History of Present Illness: Mrs. Eleanor Greenwood, a 72-year-old retired school teacher with a known history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), was brought to the emergency room by her daughter due to progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past three days. She reported increased sputum production, which was thick and yellowish, and had started experiencing a persistent cough. Despite using her prescribed bronchodilator inhaler more frequently, her symptoms did not improve. Additionally, her daughter noticed that Mrs. Greenwood was more fatigued than usual and had difficulty performing her daily activities.

Past Medical History: Mrs. Greenwood has a long-standing history of COPD, diagnosed approximately 10 years ago. She also has hypertension, controlled on lisinopril, and osteoarthritis, for which she occasionally takes ibuprofen. She is a former smoker, having quit 15 years ago after smoking one pack per day for 40 years.

Social History: Mrs. Greenwood lives alone in a small apartment and is independent in her activities of daily living. She is widowed and has two grown children who live nearby and assist with shopping and heavy chores. She enjoys reading and gardening but has been unable to tend to her plants due to her recent exacerbation. She consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.

Physical Examination: On examination, her vital signs showed tachycardia and tachypnea, with an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs revealed bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds, more pronounced in the right lower lobe. There was no evidence of peripheral edema.

Laboratory Data: Blood tests showed mild leukocytosis. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed mild respiratory acidosis with hypoxemia. Sputum culture was collected and pending results at the time of this report. Chest X-ray demonstrated hyperinflated lungs with evidence of an infiltrate in the right lower lobe, suggestive of an infectious process.

Hospital Course: Mrs. Greenwood was admitted to the hospital for acute management of her COPD exacerbation. She was placed on supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated to target possible bacterial infection, and she was started on systemic corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation. Nebulized bronchodilators were administered every four hours to alleviate bronchospasm.

Over the course of her hospital stay, Mrs. Greenwood showed gradual improvement in her respiratory status. Her oxygen saturation levels stabilized with decreased supplemental oxygen requirements, and her cough diminished significantly. Physical therapy was consulted to assist with pulmonary rehabilitation exercises to improve her exercise tolerance.

By the fifth day, Mrs. Greenwood was ambulating independently in the hallway without shortness of breath. She was successfully weaned off supplemental oxygen and transitioned to her home regimen of inhalers. After appropriate discharge planning and education on her COPD management plan, Mrs. Greenwood was discharged home with follow-up scheduled with her primary care physician and a pulmonologist.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute Myocardial Infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Marcus Higgins, a 54-year-old African American male, presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of chest pain that began while he was attending his grandson's baseball game. The pain was described as intense, central, and pressure-like, radiating to his left arm, and was associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. Mr. Higgins admitted to initially ignoring the symptoms, attributing them to heartburn, but the persistent nature of the pain prompted his ER visit.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Higgins has a medical history significant for hypertension, diagnosed 10 years ago, which he manages with lisinopril. He has had hyperlipidemia for the past 5 years, treated with atorvastatin. He reports a past episode of gout but denies any diabetes mellitus or prior cardiac issues. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Higgins works as a postal worker, a job he has held for 25 years. He lives with his wife and is actively involved in his local church community. He maintains a moderately active lifestyle, regularly walking several miles during his postal route and participating in community events. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father passed away from a heart attack at age 60.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the ER, Mr. Higgins appeared in mild distress due to pain. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg, heart rate 104 beats per minute, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation indicated tachycardia with no murmurs or gallops, and his lungs were clear to auscultation. Abdominal and extremities examination were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory tests showed elevated cardiac biomarkers (troponin I: 3.2 ng/mL), indicating myocardial injury. His lipid panel revealed elevated LDL cholesterol. An ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads, confirming an inferior wall myocardial infarction.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Higgins was promptly diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction (MI) and was started on dual antiplatelet therapy, beta-blockers, and an intravenous heparin infusion. He underwent urgent cardiac catheterization which showed a 90% stenosis in the right coronary artery. A successful percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement was performed, which resolved his chest pain. 

Following the procedure, Mr. Higgins was monitored in the coronary care unit where he continued to improve clinically. He was initiated on appropriate secondary prevention medications including aspirin, a statin, and a beta-blocker. Mr. Higgins completed cardiac rehabilitation sessions during his hospital stay and was educated on lifestyle modifications, emphasizing diet and exercise, to reduce the risk of future cardiac events.

At his postop follow-up visit two weeks later, Mr. Higgins reported feeling significantly better, without recurrence of chest pain and adhering well to his medication regimen. He was optimistic and motivated to maintain healthier lifestyle choices to prevent further cardiac incidents. His prognosis upon discharge was good, with instructions to follow up regularly with his cardiologist and primary care provider.

Her surgical history includes a cholecystectomy performed 15 years ago.

Her diet involves high sodium intake despite recommendations from her healthcare provider. She remains engaged in her local gardening club and regularly attends church services.

Respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute with oxygen saturation at 89% on room air. Lung examination revealed bilateral crackles at the bases. The cardiovascular exam showed a displaced PMI and a regular rhythm without murmurs. The abdomen was distended with shifting dullness, and bilateral pitting edema was noted up to the knees.

Furosemide was administered intravenously with significant diuresis achieved, resulting in symptomatic relief and reduced edema. Metoprolol was continued at the adjusted dose, and lisinopril was temporarily held due to renal function concerns. The patient's weight decreased by 8 pounds over three days, correlating with clinical improvement. The patient was educated on dietary modifications and the importance of medication adherence before discharge. A follow-up appointment with her cardiologist was scheduled for two weeks post-discharge.

She underwent a knee replacement five years ago and has no history of smoking or alcohol use. She takes atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. There is no significant family history of respiratory illnesses.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is widowed and lives alone in a suburban area. She is active in her local community choir and spends time gardening. Her daughter, who visits regularly, assists her with grocery shopping and other chores. She has a supportive network of neighbors and friends from the church.

record:
