He reported increasing shortness of breath over the past two days and noted that his sputum had become progressively darker. Mark initially attributed his symptoms to a seasonal cold but sought medical attention due to the escalation in severity and persistent high fevers.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mark has a history of hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril 10 mg daily. He was diagnosed with asthma in his adolescence but has had minimal exacerbations in recent years. His last asthma-related hospitalization occurred during college. He had surgery for an appendectomy at age 23. He is up-to-date with his vaccinations and had his influenza vaccination last season.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mark lives with his wife and two sons, ages 14 and 17, in a suburban neighborhood. He is a non-smoker and exercises regularly by cycling twice a week. He denies any illicit drug use and drinks alcohol socially, mainly on weekends, estimating approximately four drinks per week. His job as a teacher often exposes him to various infectious agents, given the nature of the school environment.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, Mark appeared pale and was in mild respiratory distress. His temperature was 102.1°F, with a pulse of 108 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 138/85 mmHg. Oxygen saturation was 91% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe with coarse crackles. No wheezing was noted. Heart sounds were regular, and no murmurs were detected. Abdominal and neurological examinations were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Complete blood count revealed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/µL, predominantly neutrophils. C-reactive protein levels were elevated, confirming significant inflammation. Blood cultures were pending, but an initial rapid influenza test returned positive. A chest X-ray demonstrated a right lower lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia. 

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mark was admitted to the general medical floor for intravenous antibiotics and supportive care. He received IV ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin to cover for atypical bacterial pathogens. Supplemental oxygen was provided via nasal cannula, and his oxygenation levels improved quickly. Respiratory therapy initiated a regimen of incentive spirometry to aid lung expansion. By day three, Mark's fever subsided, and his respiratory symptoms began to improve. His oxygen requirements decreased, allowing for weaning off assistance by day four. Blood cultures eventually showed no bacterial growth. After a five-day hospital stay, Mark was discharged home with a 7-day course of oral antibiotics and instructions to follow up with his primary care physician within one week for a reassessment of his respiratory status. record:
Patient Name: Samuel Richards
Age: 68
Occupation: Retired Teacher
Residence: Suburban neighborhood

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute myocardial infarction

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mr. Samuel Richards, a 68-year-old retired teacher, presented to the emergency room experiencing a sudden onset of chest pain while mowing his lawn. The pain, described as a tight, squeezing sensation, radiated to his left arm and jaw, beginning approximately two hours prior to arrival. He also reported associated symptoms of diaphoresis, nausea, and dyspnea. On arrival to the ER, he was promptly triaged due to the severity of his presentation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Richards has a known medical history of hypertension, which has been managed with lisinopril 20 mg daily for the past ten years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago, controlled with metformin 500 mg twice daily. He is also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, for which he takes atorvastatin 40 mg daily. He had a knee replacement surgery three years ago and is otherwise well.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Richards is a lifelong nonsmoker and moderately consumes alcohol, with approximately two glasses of wine weekly. He maintains an active lifestyle for his age, frequently gardening and playing golf. He lives with his wife of 45 years and has two adult children. He denies any recreational drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination in the emergency room, Mr. Richards appeared diaphoretic and anxious. His vital signs revealed hypertension, with a blood pressure reading of 150/95 mmHg, heart rate of 110 bpm, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Cardiovascular examination noted an irregular heartbeat, no murmurs, and diminished peripheral pulses. Lung auscultation was clear bilaterally.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial laboratory workup showed elevated troponin levels significantly above normal, suggestive of cardiac injury. His complete blood count and basic metabolic panel were unremarkable. An ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, diagnosing an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

HOSPITAL COURSE: Given the clinical findings, Mr. Richards was immediately taken to the cardiac catheterization lab, where angiography revealed a critical stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. He underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention with the placement of a drug-eluting stent, resulting in immediate reperfusion. Post-procedure, he was monitored in the coronary care unit, commenced on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, in addition to beta-blockers and his existing statin. Mr. Richards responded well to treatment, with stabilization of his vital signs and resolution of chest pain. He underwent a cardiac rehabilitation assessment before discharge.

FOLLOW-UP VISIT: At his one-month follow-up visit, Mr. Richards reported feeling significantly better and had returned to his regular activities, albeit taking precautions advised by his rehabilitation nurse. He expressed gratitude for the swift care and outlined his commitment to continue lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and increased physical activity as recommended by his care team. His follow-up ECG and blood work showed no new concerns, and his risk for future cardiac events was carefully discussed and managed.

record:

John reported that the pain began while he was watching television at home and persisted despite sitting and resting. Concerned about these symptoms, his wife drove him to the emergency room for further evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: John has a known history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension, for which he takes atorvastatin and lisinopril, respectively. He is overweight with a BMI of 29.5 and has a 10-year smoking history, though he quit smoking five years ago. There is a family history of coronary artery disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.

Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds with no murmurs. Lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally, and his abdomen was soft and non-tender.

Additional labs revealed total cholesterol of 220 mg/dL, LDL cholesterol of 145 mg/dL, and HDL cholesterol of 40 mg/dL.

HOSPITAL COURSE: John was promptly started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, along with intravenous nitroglycerin for pain relief. John underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention with angioplasty and stent placement (TREAT:ANGIOPLASTY). John was discharged on hospital day three with extensive counseling on lifestyle modification, including dietary changes, regular physical activity, and cessation of smoking to prevent further cardiovascular events. His discharge medications included aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. 

A FOLLOWUP_VISIT was scheduled with his cardiologist one week post-discharge for further assessment and to adjust his medication regimen as necessary. John expressed understanding of his condition and was motivated to adopt healthier habits to reduce his risk of future cardiovascular events.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute kidney injury secondary to severe dehydration.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: John Carter, a 68-year-old retired school principal, was brought to the emergency room by his wife after he experienced episodes of confusion, dizziness, and weakness over the past three days. The symptoms had started subtly, with decreased oral intake and increased fatigue, but had progressively worsened. His wife reported that he had been less attentive to his hydration, especially since the onset of a minor urinary tract infection ten days ago, which he was treating with cranberry juice and reduced fluid intake following advice from a friend. Upon arrival at the ER, Mr. Carter was diagnosed with dehydration and received intravenous fluids as part of his treatment.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a history of hypertension, managed with lisinopril, and osteoarthritis, for which he occasionally takes acetaminophen. He was treated for a mild stroke five years ago, from which he made a full recovery with no residual deficits. He is not known to have any allergies and has no prior hospitalizations in the past two years.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Carter lives with his wife in a two-story home. He is a non-smoker and drinks wine with dinner approximately twice a week. He enjoys gardening and takes regular evening walks. Mr. Carter has two adult children who visit frequently. He has no history of illicit drug use. His wife mentioned that he has been stressed recently about planning their upcoming 50th anniversary celebration, possibly contributing to his neglect in monitoring his fluid intake.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Upon examination, Mr. Carter appeared lethargic but was oriented to person and place. His vital signs showed a blood pressure of 88/56 mmHg, heart rate of 110 beats per minute, temperature of 37°C, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Mucous membranes were dry, and skin turgor was decreased. Cardiac examination revealed a regular rhythm but tachycardia. Lungs were clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination was unremarkable, and neurological examination was significant for slightly diminished cognitive function, common in his condition.

LABORATORY DATA: Blood tests revealed elevated blood urea nitrogen (34 mg/dL) and creatinine levels (2.1 mg/dL) indicating impaired kidney function. Electrolyte analysis showed hyponatremia with a serum sodium of 128 mmol/L. Urinalysis was consistent with dehydration, showing concentrated urine. Other laboratory parameters were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. Carter was admitted to the hospital for further management of acute kidney injury due to severe dehydration. Intravenous fluids were administered over the first 12 hours, leading to gradual stabilization of his blood pressure and improvement in his cognitive state. The nephrology team was consulted, and his renal function showed signs of recovery with decreased creatinine levels over the next two days. Mr. Carter was educated extensively on the importance of maintaining adequate hydration and was discharged home after four days with a follow-up appointment and clear instructions to maintain a fluid log. His wife was provided with resources to assist in ensuring adherence to the hydration regimen. Post-discharge, Mr. Carter expressed gratitude for the care received and relieved that his condition had improved without further complications.

record:
Patient Name: Samantha Lewis  
Patient ID: 67843  

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS  
Acute Exacerbation of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  
Samantha Lewis is a 62-year-old female who presented to the emergency room with complaints of worsening shortness of breath, productive cough with yellowish sputum, and wheezing for the past three days. She reports increased fatigue and difficulty performing activities of daily living. Samantha noted that her symptoms began after a recent upper respiratory tract infection, which she tried to manage at home but experienced progressive difficulty in breathing. No fever, chest pain, or hemoptysis was reported. She uses an albuterol inhaler at home but admitted to increased use over the last week without relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  
- Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), diagnosed 10 years ago  
- Hypertension  
- Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  

SOCIAL HISTORY  
Samantha is a retired school teacher who lives with her husband in a smoke-free home. She has a 30-pack-year history of smoking but quit 12 years ago. She enjoys gardening and daily walks in her neighborhood. Samantha has two adult children and mentions limited alcohol use, consuming socially on weekends.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  
On examination, the patient appeared to be in mild respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. She was afebrile, blood pressure was 140/88 mmHg, heart rate was 98 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation was 88% on room air, which improved to 94% with supplemental oxygen. Chest examination revealed bilateral wheezes but no crackles. Heart sounds were regular, and there was no peripheral edema noted.

LABORATORY DATA  
- CBC showed a white blood cell count of 11,000/mm³.  
- Arterial blood gas indicated respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.32, pCO2 of 55 mmHg, and pO2 of 60 mmHg on room air.  
- Chest X-ray revealed hyperinflation typical of COPD but no acute infiltrates.  

HOSPITAL COURSE  
Samantha was admitted to the hospital for further management of her acute COPD exacerbation. She was started on systemic corticosteroids and received nebulized bronchodilators, which resulted in improvement of her respiratory symptoms. Antibiotics were initiated due to the suspicion of a bacterial infection secondary to her recent upper respiratory illness. Blood glucose levels were monitored closely due to the steroid therapy, and her anti-diabetic medication was adjusted accordingly. Oxygen therapy was continued to maintain saturation above 90%, and Samantha participated actively in chest physiotherapy. Over the next four days, her symptoms gradually improved, and she was weaned off supplemental oxygen. Discharge planning included referral to pulmonary rehabilitation, emphasis on smoking cessation counseling, and an augmentation of her COPD management plan. Samantha was discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care physician and pulmonologist within one week of discharge.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute exacerbation of asthma

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: A 45-year-old female school teacher presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increasing shortness of breath and wheezing. Symptoms initially began with a mild cough and congestion, which she attributed to a recent change in the weather. However, over the past 24 hours, she experienced difficulty breathing, particularly at night, and required frequent use of her albuterol inhaler. Despite using a nebulizer treatment at home, her symptoms did not improve, prompting her to seek medical attention.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has a well-documented history of asthma since childhood, managed with inhaled corticosteroids and a rescue inhaler. She also has hypertension, controlled with lisinopril. No history of hospitalizations for asthma in the last five years. Vital status includes negative tobacco use, with no history of alcohol or recreational drug use.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient is a non-smoker and lives with her husband and two children in a suburb. She works as a high school English teacher and notes increased exposure to chalk dust and classroom allergens, which may exacerbate her asthma. She is regularly active, participating in yoga and walking her dog daily.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, she appeared in mild respiratory distress with an audible wheeze noted on auscultation of the lungs. Her oxygen saturation was 92% on room air, improved to 96% with supplemental oxygen. Blood pressure was 138/84 mmHg, heart rate 104 beats per minute, and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute.

LABORATORY DATA: Initial blood work was unremarkable except for a slightly elevated eosinophil count. A chest X-ray showed no definitive infiltrates, excluding pneumonia, but indicated slight hyperinflation of the lungs, consistent with asthma. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed mild respiratory acidosis.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted for observation and management of her asthma exacerbation. She was started on systemic corticosteroids and continued her bronchodilator regimen. Over the following 48 hours, her symptoms significantly improved. Her wheezing decreased, and she reported feeling less breathless. She received education on asthma management, emphasizing the importance of avoiding known triggers and maintaining adherence to her asthma action plan. She was discharged on day three with a tapering dose of oral corticosteroids and a follow-up appointment with her primary care provider to reassess her medication regimen. Home environment modifications were recommended, including the use of air filters and reducing dust exposure in her teaching environment. A follow-up pulmonary function test was scheduled to evaluate her status after completion of the corticosteroid course.

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: The patient, a 47-year-old male accountant, was admitted with intractable headache and nausea for evaluation and management.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient, Mr. Richard Stanton, began experiencing severe headaches two days prior to admission. The headaches started suddenly while he was at his desk at work, described as a pulsating pain on the right side of his head. Concurrently, he reported sensitivity to light and sound, along with episodes of nausea. He attempted to treat the headache at home with over-the-counter analgesics, but they provided no relief. After the onset of the headache, he visited the emergency room, where a clinical evaluation led to the diagnosis of migraine with aura and he was admitted for further observation and pain management.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Mr. Stanton has a medical history significant for hypertension, which is controlled with lisinopril. He also has a history of seasonal allergies and has previously suffered from episodic migraine headaches, although not this severe. No known drug allergies. He had an appendectomy at age 24 without complications.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Mr. Stanton lives with his wife and two children in the suburbs. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially, typically preferring wine on weekends. He works as an accountant and mentions that his job can be quite stressful, particularly during the tax season. He exercises regularly, running three times a week, and follows a heart-healthy diet as advised for managing his hypertension.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient appeared in moderate distress due to headache pain. Vital signs on admission showed a blood pressure of 142/88 mmHg, heart rate of 78 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and temperature of 98.6°F. Neurological examination was significant for photophobia but no focal neurological deficits. Fundoscopic examination was within normal limits. Cardiovascular, respiratory, and gastrointestinal examinations were unremarkable.

LABORATORY DATA: Routine blood work including complete blood count, electrolytes, and metabolic panel were within normal limits. A head CT scan performed in the ER to rule out intracranial pathology was negative for acute intracranial abnormalities.

HOSPITAL COURSE: During his admission, Mr. Stanton was started on a regimen of intravenous fluids and was given sumatriptan for acute migraine treatment, in addition to an antiemetic to address the nausea. Pain management strategies also included non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and eventual administration of a corticosteroid due to the persistence of pain. Over the next 24 hours, his symptoms began to subside. Neurology was consulted, and it was recommended that Mr. Stanton initiate a prophylactic treatment to decrease the frequency of migraine attacks, with options discussed being propranolol or topiramate. Mr. Stanton was educated on lifestyle modifications, including stress management and avoidance of known migraine triggers such as caffeine and lack of sleep. By the third hospital day, his headache had resolved, and he was discharged home in good condition with follow-up arranged for outpatient neurologic evaluation.
nl_query: Did the patient visit the emergency room for an onset of a headache and receive a diagnosis of migraine with subsequent pain management treatment?

record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: A 28-year-old male, John Doe, presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of progressively worsening abdominal pain, initially periumbilical and now localized in the right lower quadrant. He reported associated nausea and anorexia, but no emesis or diarrhea. He denied any similar previous episodes or recent travel. John is otherwise healthy and did not take over-the-counter analgesics prior to presentation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: John's medical history is significant for bronchial asthma since childhood, well-managed with inhaled corticosteroids as needed. No prior surgeries, no history of allergies, and he is up-to-date on vaccinations including the annual influenza vaccine.

SOCIAL HISTORY: John is a software engineer living in an urban area. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol socially, approximately 2-3 drinks per week. He exercises regularly, attending a local gym three times a week. He lives with his partner and does not have any children. No significant family history of gastrointestinal diseases was noted.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, John was afebrile, with vital signs showing mild tachycardia. Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant, with rebound tenderness and guarding. Rovsing’s sign was positive, and bowel sounds were diminished. No other significant findings were noted on cardiovascular or respiratory examination.

LABORATORY DATA: Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³, predominantly neutrophils. C-reactive protein was elevated. Liver function tests, serum electrolytes, and renal function tests were within normal limits.

HOSPITAL COURSE: John was admitted with a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed an enlarged and inflamed appendix. He was started on intravenous fluids, and antibiotics (ceftriaxone and metronidazole) were initiated pre-operatively. John underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy the following morning. Post-operatively, he recovered well with significant improvement in symptoms. His pain was managed effectively with oral analgesics, and he was mobilized and on a regular diet by post-operative day two. John was discharged on post-operative day three with oral antibiotics to complete a course, and with instructions to avoid strenuous activities for two weeks.

Follow-up with the surgical outpatient clinic was arranged for two weeks post-discharge, at which time John's incision sites were healing well with no signs of infection. John returned to work after his follow-up appointment and continued with a full recovery.
